pending.headline: When Sovereignty Becomes Negotiable
pending.content:
The President of the United States has announced that he will impose tariffs on eight NATO allies, including the United Kingdom, unless Denmark agrees to sell Greenland to Washington.

Read that again.

Not tariffs based on trade imbalances. Not tariffs as leverage in a security negotiation. Tariffs as the price for refusing to surrender sovereign territory.

When asked if he would rule out using military force to take Greenland, the President replied: "No comment."

This is not about Greenland's strategic value. This is about whether territorial integrity is still a principle that governs relations between free nations, or merely a preference that can be coerced away through economic threats.

**The Mechanism Matters**

I have served in government. I understand that nations pursue strategic interests. The United States has legitimate security concerns in the Arctic. Greenland's location matters to continental defense.

But how a nation pursues those interests reveals what kind of nation it is.

The President frames this as about "National and World Security." That framing does important work. It suggests that opposition to the demand is not merely unwise but dangerous, not merely disagreement but dereliction.

Notice what has disappeared from the conversation: any reference to the consent of the governed.

Greenland is home to 56,000 people. They are not a commodity to be purchased. They possess the right to self-determination under international law, recognized in the UN Charter, Article 1. Their premier has stated clearly: "We are not for sale."

That should end the discussion in any framework where popular sovereignty matters.

It has not ended the discussion.

**When Alliances Become Conditional**

The tariff threat targets eight nations. All are NATO members. All are democracies. All stood with the United States after September 11th under Article 5, the mutual defense clause that declares an attack on one is an attack on all.

Denmark lost 43 soldiers in Afghanistan fighting alongside American forces. Norway lost 10. The United Kingdom lost 457.

They did not die protecting trade advantages. They died because we invoked a treaty that says democracies defend each other.

Now that treaty obligation is being made conditional on compliance with a territorial demand.

The Danish foreign minister stated it plainly: "You can't threaten your way to ownership of Greenland."

That is not rhetoric. That is a statement about what separates law-governed nations from those where power is the only currency that matters.

If sovereignty is negotiable when a stronger power demands it, then every treaty is merely a pause between coercions. Every border is temporary. Every alliance lasts only as long as the stronger party finds it convenient.

**The Normalization**

This is not the first time extraordinary measures have been proposed in the name of security. The question is whether they become ordinary.

In 2002, the Authorization for Use of Military Force passed Congress to target those responsible for 9/11. It has since been invoked to justify military action in 18 countries, against groups that did not exist in 2001, without further congressional authorization.

In 2008, the Treasury Department received emergency authority to stabilize the financial system. The Troubled Asset Relief Program was sold as temporary and extraordinary. Elements of that emergency authority have been extended and renewed for 15 years.

Extraordinary becomes normal when we stop asking whether the initial justification still applies.

The President's demand is framed as imperative security policy. But security for whom? Greenland already hosts Pituffik Space Base, operated jointly by the United States and Denmark under treaty. NORAD conducts routine operations there with Danish cooperation.

The strategic access already exists. What is being demanded is not access but ownership.

**What Citizens Should Ask**

The question is not whether Greenland has strategic value.

The question is whether the United States can use economic coercion to force a democratic ally to surrender sovereign territory.

If the answer is yes, then what principle constrains that power? If tariffs can be imposed until Denmark yields Greenland, can they be imposed until Norway yields Svalbard? Until Canada yields the Northwest Passage?

Once sovereignty becomes negotiable through economic threat, what border is secure?

The President has also stated he will not rule out military force. When pressed, he said "no comment." That is not the same as saying no.

In 1939, Germany demanded that Poland cede the Free City of Danzig and grant extraterritorial access through the Polish Corridor. The demand was framed as addressing legitimate security concerns and correcting historical injustices. Poland refused. War followed.

I am not predicting war. I am noting that territorial demands backed by threats have a history. That history does not end well.

**The Test of Principle**

The United States was founded on the proposition that governments derive their just powers from the consent of the governed. That principle is not merely domestic. It is the basis of the international order we built after 1945.

That order has flaws. It has failed often. But it rests on the idea that nations do not simply take what they can, that borders are not merely facts of power, that sovereignty matters.

If we abandon that principle when it becomes inconvenient, we abandon the only framework that prevents international relations from becoming purely a question of force.

The European Union's foreign policy chief said it clearly: "Sovereignty is not for trade."

That is not defiance. That is a statement of the principle that makes peaceful coexistence possible.

When the President imposes these tariffs on February 1st, as he has promised "100%" he will do, the question will not be whether European economies suffer. The question will be whether economic coercion in pursuit of territorial demands has become an acceptable tool of American statecraft.

If it has, then we are no longer the nation that wrote the Atlantic Charter or designed the United Nations. We are something else.

The test is not whether we can take Greenland. The test is whether we believe that power alone decides what is ours.

That question, still unanswered, is why this moment matters.

pending.headline: When the President Decides What "Cause" Means
pending.content:
I spent years in government service. I learned early that certain institutions exist not to make governing easier, but to make it harder in specific, necessary ways.

The Federal Reserve is one of those institutions.

Congress created it in 1913 after watching how politics and money interact when no barrier stands between them. The pattern was consistent: financial panics in the 1890s, political pressure for easy credit, economic collapse, repeat. The lesson was not complicated. When presidents can manipulate monetary policy for short-term political gain, the economy destabilizes in predictable ways.

So Congress built a wall. Not an absolute wall, but a procedural one. Federal Reserve governors serve fixed terms. They can be removed for malfeasance, but not for disagreement. Not for setting interest rates the president dislikes. Not for pursuing policies that serve long-term stability over short-term popularity.

That wall has held for 112 years.

This week, the Supreme Court considers whether to demolish it.

## The Argument Being Made

The legal question appears narrow. President Trump seeks to fire Lisa Cook, a Fed governor appointed by President Biden. The stated cause: irregularities in mortgage applications for two properties. Cook denies wrongdoing. Her lawyers note that four Cabinet members and the deputy attorney general have made similar applications without prosecution. The official who raised the allegations, Bill Pulte, has relatives who did the same.

But the narrow question hides a structural claim.

The administration argues that once the president determines cause exists, that determination is unreviewable by courts. The president's judgment is final. No independent tribunal examines the evidence. No standard of proof applies. If the president says cause exists, cause exists.

This is not about Lisa Cook's mortgages.

This is about whether "for cause" means anything at all.

I have seen this move before, in different contexts. A legal protection remains on paper while its meaning gets hollowed out. The words stay the same. The substance vanishes. You still need "cause" to fire a Fed governor, technically. But cause becomes whatever the president says it is, whenever he says it, without review.

That is not a protection. That is permission.

## What Powell Said

Jerome Powell, the Fed chair Trump himself appointed in 2018, is known for careful language and institutional deference. He avoided confrontation even as Trump publicly called him incompetent or crooked. He stayed quiet when the administration opened a criminal investigation into his Senate testimony about building renovations.

Then Powell spoke clearly.

"This new threat is not about my testimony last June or about the renovation of federal reserve buildings. Those are pretexts. The threat of criminal charges is a consequence of the Federal Reserve setting interest rates based on our best assessment of what will serve the public rather than following the preferences of the president."

Powell used the word "pretexts." That is the language of someone who has watched procedure become theater, who has seen legal mechanisms deployed not for their stated purpose but to achieve a different end.

He is describing what happens when the question is not whether cause exists, but whether claiming cause is sufficient.

## Why Congress Built the Wall

The argument for presidential control has constitutional weight. Article II vests executive power in the president. Proponents argue he cannot execute that power if he cannot remove officials who resist his direction.

But Congress has constitutional power too. Article I grants it authority to structure how government operates, including creating institutions that check executive discretion. The first Congress, which included many Founders, created the First Bank of the United States in 1791 with term-limited leadership precisely to insulate financial policy from direct presidential control.

They had watched how monarchs manipulate currency. They understood that elected executives face the same temptations.

The question is not whether the president has executive power. The question is whether that power extends to controlling monetary policy through personnel removal, when Congress specifically designed an institution to prevent that control.

Daniel Tarullo, a former Fed governor and Harvard law professor, explains the economic reality: "Presidents of both parties always want interest rates to go down, particularly in election years, but that inevitably destabilizes the economy."

When long-term rates rise because markets fear inflation, mortgages and business investment suffer. The political incentive is always for short-term stimulus. The economic necessity is often for long-term restraint. Congress created the Fed to resolve that tension by removing the decision from political calculation.

If the president can fire Fed governors who resist his preferences, that resolution fails. The Fed becomes what it was designed not to be: an instrument of presidential economic policy.

## The Normalization Pattern

I am watching a familiar pattern unfold.

First, you claim emergency authority for extraordinary circumstances. Then you find ordinary circumstances that arguably fit the emergency framework. Then the framework becomes routine. Then the exception becomes the rule.

The administration is not arguing it can fire Fed governors at will. It is arguing it can fire them for cause, and that presidential determination of cause is unreviewable.

But unreviewable determination is functionally equivalent to at-will removal. If I can fire you whenever I decide sufficient cause exists, and no one can challenge that decision, then I can fire you whenever I want. The "for cause" requirement becomes a formality, a box to check, not a constraint on power.

Every living Fed chair except Powell has signed briefs opposing this change. Treasury secretaries from both parties have too. So have prominent economists across the political spectrum. Jamie Dimon, not known for alarmism, warns of "reverse consequences" including higher inflation and increased borrowing costs.

These are not partisans defending bureaucratic turf. These are people who understand what happens when short-term political pressure drives monetary policy.

## What the Court Said Before

The Supreme Court, in recent emergency docket rulings, allowed Trump to remove other agency heads with term protections. But in one opinion, the conservative majority noted the Fed is different: "a uniquely structured, quasi-private entity that follows in the distinct historical tradition of the First and Second Banks of the United States."

That distinction recognizes something important. Some institutions exist not to implement presidential policy but to constrain it. They are countermajoritarian by design, built to resist immediate political pressure in service of longer-term stability.

The question before the Court is whether that distinction still holds. Whether the constitutional structure allows Congress to create institutions genuinely independent of direct presidential control, or whether Article II executive power ultimately subsumes everything.

## The Question Citizens Should Ask

This is not about whether Lisa Cook should be a Fed governor. This is not about whether Trump's economic policy preferences are sound. This is not even about whether the Federal Reserve as currently structured is the best possible design.

This is about whether presidential power over monetary policy has effective limits.

If the president can remove Fed governors by claiming cause and that claim is unreviewable, then future presidents inherit that power. A president who wants higher interest rates to fight inflation can fire governors who resist. A president who wants lower rates to stimulate growth can fire governors who disagree. The Fed becomes responsive to whoever holds office, not to any consistent standard or statutory mandate.

The wall Congress built in 1913 was not meant to last forever unchanged. But it was meant to be removed deliberately, through legislation, not eroded through interpretations that preserve the form while eliminating the substance.

I am not arguing the president should never be able to remove Federal Reserve governors. I am arguing that if we change that 112-year-old protection, we should change it knowingly, through democratic process, not through legal claims that redefine "cause" until it means "disagreement."

Paul Clement, who served as solicitor general under George W. Bush, is arguing this case for Cook and the Fed's independence. Powell himself will be in the courtroom. That tells you something about what people who have served, across administrations, understand about what is at stake.

The question is not whether the president wants compliant officials. Every president does.

The question is whether monetary policy should be insulated from that desire, and whether Congress has authority to create that insulation.

The answer to that question shapes whether we have independent institutions, or whether we have institutions that answer to whoever currently holds power.

That question, framed clearly, is why this moment matters.

I served in the uniformed services. I worked in government agencies where oversight existed, where inspectors general mattered, where the line between the White House and prosecutorial power was not crossed because it could not be crossed without consequences.

That line has now been crossed. Repeatedly. Openly.

The NPR report catalogs what has happened in one year. The catalog itself is the problem. When you need a multi-section graphic essay to track the erosion of constitutional norms, you are no longer talking about policy disputes. You are talking about a different kind of government.

This is not about partisan alignment. This is about whether the system designed in Philadelphia in 1787 can withstand a presidency that treats its constraints as suggestions.

## The Architecture Assumed Restraint

The Constitution did not anticipate a president who would fire inspectors general for doing their jobs. It did not envision a Justice Department weaponized against political opponents while the president announces his targets on social media. It did not plan for congressional majorities that would watch the executive branch seize spending authority, implement sweeping tariffs without meaningful legislative debate, and respond with silence.

The Founders built a system of checks and balances. What they assumed, but could not guarantee, was that people in power would fear violating those checks.

That fear is gone.

When a president pardons those convicted of violently attacking the Capitol, he is not merely exercising constitutional authority. He is declaring that political loyalty supersedes the rule of law. When his administration defies court orders, intimidates journalists, and threatens prosecutors who investigate allies, he is testing whether the system will enforce its own rules.

So far, the answer has been equivocal.

## Normalization Is the Danger

What makes this moment dangerous is not any single act. It is the speed at which the extraordinary becomes ordinary.

A year ago, the idea that the president would openly direct prosecutions of political enemies would have been unthinkable. Now it is reported as fact, cataloged alongside other actions, and the news cycle moves on.

A year ago, the systematic dismantling of public health institutions based on a cabinet secretary's personal theories would have triggered congressional investigations. Now it is policy.

A year ago, Congress would not have tolerated the executive branch unilaterally withholding appropriated funds. Now it happens, and the legislative branch shrugs.

This is how republics slip. Not through a single coup. Through a thousand small adjustments in what is considered acceptable. Through the quiet recalibration of what "checks and balances" means until it means very little at all.

## The Founders Warned Us

Madison wrote in Federalist 51: "If men were angels, no government would be necessary. If angels were to govern men, neither external nor internal controls on government would be necessary."

The system was designed for people who would seek power and misuse it. What the Founders could not fully account for was a scenario where one branch of government would actively assist another in dismantling the controls meant to restrain them both.

The question is not whether President Trump is popular with his base. The question is whether popularity justifies the systematic elimination of accountability mechanisms.

Lincoln faced a genuine existential crisis, a civil war that threatened the nation's survival. Even then, he submitted to judicial review, accepted the legitimacy of elections during wartime, and defended the principle that no president is above the law. His suspension of habeas corpus was contested in court, debated in Congress, and ultimately constrained.

What we face now is not a civil war. It is a claim that electoral victory grants authority to disregard institutional constraints whenever they prove inconvenient. That is not a muscular presidency. That is something else.

## The Test Is Here

The question citizens should be asking is this: What happens when the system designed to check power assumes that those in power will respect its legitimacy?

We are finding out.

Federal judges issue orders. The administration ignores them. Congress holds the purse. The executive branch withholds funds anyway. Inspectors general investigate. They are fired. Journalists report. They are threatened. Scientists provide data. They are silenced.

Each act alone might be debated on its merits. Taken together, they form a pattern. That pattern is not compatible with a government of laws.

The midterm elections will matter. Whether Congress reasserts its constitutional role will matter. Whether courts enforce their orders will matter. Whether citizens demand accountability will matter.

But what matters most is whether we recognize what is happening while it is happening. Whether we see the difference between legitimate policy disputes and the systematic dismantling of the mechanisms that make self-government possible.

The architecture of the republic is still standing. The question is whether anyone is still willing to defend it.

That question, unanswered, is why we must answer it now.

In Union there is Strength.
